Welcome to A-Level-Project’s documentation!¶

game.py¶

class source.game.Game(start_screen)¶

Class to initialise pygame and contain the main game loop. Initialises the game surface and the pygame Clock.

static quit() → None¶

Quit out of pygame. Method can be static as it does not require access to any attributes defined in self.

Returns

None

run() → None¶

Runs the game. Instantiates a Controller object then creates the game loop. Handles passing of events to the controller as well as flipping the display each frame.

Returns

None

source.game.main() → None¶

Creates a while loop to instantiate a new Game object each time the user restarts, or quits out of the program when prompted.

Returns

None

controller.py¶

class source.controller.ControlScheme¶

Class to contain the current keybindings for any actions that occur during gameplay.

class source.controller.Controller(game_surface: pygame.Surface, screen_width: int, screen_height: int)¶

Link class which acts as a bridge between the main game and all other instances being used throughout the game.

Prevents classes knowing about other classes which are unrelated, reducing code complexity.

All classes communicate to each other through this class, unless other classes are directly related, such as the Wave and Enemy class.

check_collisions() → None¶

Check if any sprites are colliding such that a missile or enemy needs to be removed from the display.

Returns

None

check_if_wave_finished() → None¶

Checks if the current wave is complete, ie, all the enemies have either hit the bottom of the screen or been hit by a missile.

Returns

None

create_new_wave() → None¶

Instantiate a new wave object after calculating the correct number of enemies to be spawned in the wave. Increments the current wave number by 1.

Returns

None

create_new_wave_if_required() → None¶

Checks if the conditions for the creation of a new wave have been met. Calls create_new_wave when required.

Returns

None

enemy_hit_ground() → None¶

Callback function passed into Wave on instantiation. Provides a method for the enemies to tell the Controller class when to decrement the lives counter.

Returns

None

get_what_needs_to_be_updated() → list¶

Return a list of all the instances that need to be updated in any given frame. Only updates what needs to be updated, ie, does not update the game_over screen if the game_over conditions have not been met.

Returns

List of all instances that need to be updated in a given frame

process_event(event: pygame.event.Event) → None¶

Process the passed in event, sending a signal to the reticle, or firing a missile if necessary.

TODO: Reformat this to use switch/case type syntax to prevent large IF blocks?

Parameters

event – Any pygame.event.Event instance

Returns

None

trigger_fire_missile() → None¶

Check if the maximum amount of missiles are already on the screen and instantiate a new one if the limit have not been reached.

Returns

None

update_all() → None¶

Updates all instances fetched by get_what_needs_to_be_updated() and runs game_over logic.

Returns

None

source.controller.calculate_enemies_for_wave(initial_enemies: int, wave_number: int, constant: float) → int¶

Equation to calculate the number of enemies for any given wave. Exponential equation ensures the difficulty progression is non-linear meaning the number of enemies does not increase at a constant rate.

Parameters

  • initial_enemies – The starting number of enemies for the zeroth wave

  • wave_number – The current wave number

  • constant – The enemy constant, usually a float between 0 and 1

Returns

Integer number of enemies for the given wave

source.controller.calculate_wave_spawn_period(wave_number: int) → float¶

Equation to calculate the amount of time enemies have to spawn for any given wave. Equates to 5√(4x) + 5 where x is the wave number. This gives a surd curve meaning that for the first 5 waves, the amount of time increases at a faster rate than for later waves, hence increasing the late-game difficulty.

Parameters

wave_number – The current wave number

Returns

Float amount of seconds that enemies will spawn over

source.controller.get_rect_of_instance(instance) → pygame.Rect¶

Gets the pygame.Rect of a given instance’s image attribute Returns a pygame.Rect in the correct position.

Parameters

instance – An object that has an image attribute

Returns

pygame.Rect in the correct position

source.controller.is_colliding(rect1: pygame.Rect, rect2: pygame.Rect) → bool¶

Takes two pygame.Rect instances and returns a bool indicating whether or not they are currently colliding.

The pygame colliderect function already provides this functionality, this implementation simply makes it easier to read, more pythonic.

Parameters

  • rect1 – pygame.Rect instance

  • rect2 – pygame.Rect instance

Returns

Bool to indicate whether or not the rects are colliding

wave.py¶

class source.wave.Wave(number_of_enemies: int, time_limit: Union[int, float], game_surface: pygame.Surface, screen_width: int, screen_height: int, hit_ground_func: Callable, wave_num: int, font_size: int)¶

Class to represent a ‘wave’ of enemies. Controls how enemies are spawned over a specific time frame using a sprite group to contain all enemies for any specific wave.

draw_wave_number() → None¶

Renders and draws the current wave number onto the game surface. Acts as an indicator to the user as to when the wave ends/a new wave begins.

Returns

None

mark_incomplete() → None¶

Marks the wave as unfinished.

Returns

None

register_enemies() → None¶

Adds a specific amount of enemies to the sprite group, all are spawned at the same time.

Note

This method is no longer used.

Returns

None

register_enemy() → None¶

Adds a single enemy to the sprite group. Enemies spawn as soon as they are registered.

Returns

None

register_new_enemy_if_required() → None¶

Checks whether sufficient time has passed to spawn a new enemy. If it has, a new enemy is registered.

Returns

None

update() → None¶

Calls the update method on the enemies sprite group and increments the frames since start counter. Draws the wave counter onto the surface.

Returns

None

enemy.py¶

class source.enemy.Enemy(sprite_group: pygame.sprite.Group, game_surface: pygame.Surface, screen_width: int, screen_height: int, hit_ground_func: Callable, mark_wave_incomplete_func: Callable)¶

Represents a game enemy, what the player is trying to prevent from reaching the bottom of the screen.

create_animation_frames() → None¶

Takes the spritesheet and splits it into a list of animation frames.

Returns

None

draw_frame() → None¶

Draws the current frame of the animation onto the game surface

Returns

None

generate_positions_and_velocities() → None¶

Defines the start and end coordinates, calculates the velocity vector required to move between them.

Returns

None

move() → None¶

Moves the enemy by the amount defined by its velocity.

Returns

None

next_frame() → None¶

Defines the index of the current frame, looping back to 0 once all frames have been shown.

Returns

random_aim_position() → tuple¶

Defines a random x coordinate at the bottom of the screen where the enemy is aimed towards.

Returns

Tuple x, y coordinate

random_start_position() → tuple¶

Defines a random x coordinate at the top of the screen where the enemy spawns.

Returns

Tuple x, y coordinate

rotate_all_frames() → None¶

Rotates all frames of the enemy animation to point towards the enemy’s aim position.

Returns

None

update() → None¶

Updates the enemy’s position on the screen, also checks whether or not it has reached the bottom of the screen.

Returns

Parameters

  • maxn – Int upper bound

  • minn – Int lower bound

Returns

class source.lives.Lives(game_surface: pygame.Surface, screen_width: int, screen_height: int, font_size: int, lives: int)¶

Class to contain current lives counter functionality.

decrement() → None¶

Decrements the current life count by 1 each time it is called. Life count cannot be less than 0.

Returns

None

update() → None¶

Draws the life counter onto the game surface each time this is called.

Returns

utils.py¶

source.utils.get_angle_positions(x: Union[int, float], y: Union[int, float], end_x: Union[int, float], end_y: Union[int, float], offset: int) → float¶

Calculates the angle between any set of two x, y coordinates.

Parameters

  • x – Start x coordinate

  • y – Start y coordinate

  • end_x – Final x coordinate

  • end_y – Final y coordinate

  • offset – An angle amount in degrees to offset the output by

Returns

Angle in degrees

source.utils.vector_from_positions(x: Union[int, float], y: Union[int, float], end_x: Union[int, float], end_y: Union[int, float], constant: Union[int, float]) → tuple¶

Calculates the vector required to navigate from an x, y coordinate to a different x, y coordinate.

Parameters

  • x – Start x coordinate

  • y – Start y coordinate

  • end_x – Final x coordinate

  • end_y – Final y coordinate

  • constant – Velocity constant

Returns

Tuple x, y velocity vector
